Dark Message

Also the default color style if no styling is applied.

Blue Message

If you add a message-blue class in place of the message class, it will style the whole message box as that color style.

Red Message

Just another example, but message-red is being applied this time. You only need to replace the message class for this to work.

Green Message

This time message-green. You can probably already tell it's the same colors as boba's palette and you're right.

Purple Message

This is message-purple. Oh you're wondering about how to change the background? Just add that bg-COLOR class and even change that with the lighten-# or darken-# class

Yellow Message, but wait...

You can also change the text's color if the default white isn't doing it for you. Just add text-COLOR to the tag holding the text. This works both for the header text and the body text. Make sure it's not on the same tag as message-body!!!

Getting Funky

You can also completely change the design of the message component. Only keep that message class and add message-header-COLOR or message-body-COLOR, or even both, to style the message!

Background too?

Of course! We just go back to our roots and add bg-COLOR with lighten-# or darken-# along with the message class
